questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of multiple lesions on his lower extremity. The lesions are increasing in size and are not painful or pruritic. He does not have lymphadenopathy. He works at a garden center. He lives in Mississippi. Medications include abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine. His temperature is 37.7°C (98.8°F), pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Examination shows multiple lesions on both heels; some are elevated. There are two similar lesions on the chest. An image of the patient's right heel is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450/mm3. A skin biopsy shows multiple spindle-shaped cells and leukocyte infiltration. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Infections with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) are a common AIDS-defining condition. Unlike the Kaposi sarcoma seen in this patient, however, MAC infections do not manifest with skin lesions but with fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, and abdominal pain. It also rarely occurs in patients with a CD4 cell count > 50/mm3.

B) CORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a malignant, highly vascularized tumor that most commonly affects the skin and is caused by human herpesvirus 8. It is the most common HIV-associated tumor and can occur at any CD4 count. This tumor initially manifests with multiple rapidly growing, painless cutaneous tumors that typically affect the face, chest, heels, and oral cavity. If left untreated, the tumor may disseminate to the organs (e.g., gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract). KS skin lesions resemble those of bacillary angiomatosis; histology is required to differentiate between the conditions. The diagnosis is confirmed with skin biopsy findings of spindle-shaped cells, leukocyte infiltration, and signs of angiogenesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infections can cause bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients. The infection leads to vascular proliferation, which can manifest as multiple red papules that bleed easily. Biopsy findings of the lesion may also show an inflammatory infiltrate, but spindle-shaped cells are not characteristic of bacillary angiomatosis. Moreover, bacillary angiomatosis is most common in patients with a CD4 count < 100/mm3.

D) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a fungus that causes sporotrichosis, a disease that is mainly transmitted through contact with contaminated soil or plants, e.g., while gardening. Several red to purple nodules may develop around the initial lesion, which forms at the inoculation site (typically the hands or arms). While this patient's risk of contracting sporotrichosis is increased because of his profession, biopsy findings are consistent with Kaposi sarcoma, which is not associated with S. schenckii infection.
Image Description:

Photograph of the left arm of a patient

There are several large, nodular lesions on the left arm. The largest and most distal lesion is ulcerated. The chain-like pattern of these lesions follows a lymphocutaneous distribution.

This is the typical appearance of lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection that primarily manifests with acute pneumonia but that can disseminate and cause erythema nodosum. While erythema nodosum also presents with subcutaneous nodules that are red to blue in color, they are painful and typically located on the pretibial surfaces. Biopsy findings show a dimorphic fungus and spherules filled with endospores. Additionally, coccidioidomycosis is endemic to the southwestern United States and not likely in a patient from Mississippi with no history of recent travel.
Image Description:

Multiple erythematous maculonodular lesions of varying shapes and sizes (green overlay) distributed on both pretibial surfaces.

Those findings, especially when seen on the anterior leg, are typical of erythema nodosum.
The erythematous appearance indicates that those lesions have likely developed within the last 7 days (afterwards, erythema nodosum lesions usually turn bluish and then yellow-brownish).

F) INCORRECT:

In patients with HIV, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infections can cause oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL). However, OHL affects the oral mucosa, and the lesions are typically painless, nonscrapable white plaques with a feathery or hairy appearance. While chronic persistence of EBV is also associated with several tumor entities (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma, endemic Burkitt lymphoma), cutaneous lesions would not be the initial manifestation of these diseases.
Image Description:

A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

G) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is a fungus that causes tinea, but it is not associated with Kaposi sarcoma. While the condition can affect any body part and could occur on the heels and chest simultaneously, the lesions manifest as pruritic, erythematous plaques with scaling, raised borders. A KOH stain of a skin sample would show a fungus with segmented hyphae.
Image Description:

Pronounced, well-demarcated erythema with scaling is visible between the third and fourth toes.

This appearance is typical of tinea pedis, which typically manifests with severe pruritus.
questions.hint: The purple-bluish lesions seen in this patient with HIV are consistent with Kaposi sarcomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the physician because of multiple lesions on his chest and lower extremities. The lesions have progressively increased in size and are not painful or pruritic. He was diagnosed with HIV seven years ago. Current medications include abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine. A photograph of the lesions is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450/mm3. A skin biopsy shows multiple spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltrate. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral agent used in the treatment of several viral infections, especially cytomegalovirus (CMV). Infection with CMV is common in immunocompromised patients, including patients with HIV. However, the most common sequelae include CMV retinitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis – not skin lesions. Ganciclovir would not be effective in the treatment of KS.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitazoxanide is an antiparasitic agent used in the treatment of Cryptosporidium parvum and Giardia lamblia infection. This patient with HIV is at increased risk of protozoa infection. However, these parasites cause chronic nonbloody diarrhea without any cutaneous manifestations. Nitazoxanide would not be effective in the treatment of KS.

C) CORRECT:

Alpha-interferon (IFN-α) is a biologic modifier that can be used in the treatment of KS. This type of sarcoma can be caused by HHV-8 infection and is an AIDS-defining illness. KS can occur at any CD4+ count but is more likely to develop if CD4+ count is < 500/mm3. How IFN-α fights cancer cells is not fully understood; upregulation of the immune response is thought to play a role. IFN-α is also used in the treatment of hepatitis B and C infections.

D) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of severe fungal infections such as histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, and cryptococcosis, which can occasionally present with cutaneous manifestations. However, these conditions are typically associated with a lower CD4+ count (< 250/mm3 in coccidiomycosis, < 150/mm3 in histoplasmosis and cryptococcosis) and other features of these fungal infections (e.g., pneumonia-like illness in coccidiomycosis and histoplasmosis, meningitis in cryptococcosis) are not present. Amphotericin B would not be effective in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used for the treatment of infectious diseases such as Bacillary angiomatosis, a condition caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae. Bacillary angiomatosis is often seen in patients with AIDS. It can also manifest with multiple painless violaceous nodules on the skin and is, therefore, an important differential diagnosis for Kaposi sarcoma. However, a biopsy of these lesions is likely to show neutrophilic infiltration rather than the lymphocytic infiltration seen in this patient. Doxycycline would not be effective in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.
Image Description:

Two angioma-like lesions with a surrounding erythematous halo are visible.

This immunocompromised patient was diagnosed with bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella quintana.
questions.hint: In a patient with HIV, multiple painless violaceous skin lesions that progress in size point toward Kaposi sarcoma (KS). Spindle cells and lymphocytic infiltrate on skin biopsy confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man with HIV comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of intermittent diarrhea and abdominal pain. Abdominal examination shows mild, diffuse tenderness throughout the lower quadrants. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 180/mm3. Colonoscopy shows multiple hemorrhagic nodules in the rectum and descending colon. Polymerase chain reaction of the lesions is positive for HHV-8. Histologic examination of the lesions is most likely to show which of the following findings?

choices.text: Cords of atypical cells with extracellular mucin
Enlarged cells with ground-glass nuclei and central clearing
Enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusion bodies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A biopsy of colonic lesions showing cords of atypical cells with extracellular mucin is concerning for colorectal mucinous adenocarcinoma, which could explain this patient's diarrhea and abdominal pain. Colon cancers may also cause GI bleeding, but it would usually occur at a rate too slow to support a colonoscopy finding of occult hemorrhage. In addition, mucinous adenocarcinoma is not associated with HHV-8 infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of tissue biopsied from a colonic polyp (H&E stain; 400x magnification)

The hyperchromatic purple (highly basophilic) cells in the center of this image are colonic epithelial cells. They have hyperchromatic cytoplasm and large, mitotic nuclei (red overlay), which are signs of malignancy. The cells surround pools of extracellular mucin (green overlay). Inflammatory cells are visible in the stroma surrounding the glands.

Mucinous pools that make up at least 50% of the tumor mass are characteristic of mucinous adenocarcinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Enlarged cells with ground-glass nuclei and central clearing describe “Orphan Annie eye” nuclear inclusions, which are characteristic of papillary thyroid carcinoma and autoimmune thyroiditis (i.e., Hashimoto disease). Neither of these conditions is associated with HHV-8 infection or colonic lesions. In addition, the patient has neither a neck mass to suggest thyroid cancer nor metabolic symptoms (e.g., weight changes, temperature intolerance) to suggest thyroiditis.

C) INCORRECT:

A finding of enlarged cells with intranuclear inclusion bodies in an immunocompromised patient with gastrointestinal symptoms is concerning for CMV colitis. Patients with CMV colitis can present with abdominal pain and bloody diarrhea. However, endoscopy of CMV colitis usually shows linear ulcers rather than the hemorrhagic nodules seen in this patient. Furthermore, CMV infections (e.g., colitis, retinitis, esophagitis) in patients with HIV typically present when the CD4+ count is < 50 cells/mm3 and would be unlikely in this patient with a CD4+ count of 180/mm3.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a lung tissue specimen (H&E stain; very high magnification) from a patient with AIDS and an active CMV infection

The large cell visible near the center of the image is an enlarged pneumocyte, containing a basophilic intranuclear inclusion body (yellow overlay) surrounded by a bright halo (blue overlay). Smaller granular inclusion bodies can be seen in the cytoplasm (arrowheads).

The owl's eye appearance of the intranuclear inclusion body indicates a CMV infection.

D) INCORRECT:

Polygonal cells with tennis racket-shaped organelles describe Birbeck granules, which are seen in Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Unlike this patient's condition, Langerhans cell histiocytosis rarely involves the gastrointestinal tract. It also would not lead to a low CD4 count and has no known association with HHV-8 infection.

E) CORRECT:

Vascular lesions showing spindle-shaped cells with lymphocytic infiltration are consistent with Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining condition that is caused by HHV-8 infection. Kaposi sarcomas originate from endothelial cells and usually manifest with asymptomatic vascular tumors of the skin. These tumors can also involve the lymph nodes and gastrointestinal tract, potentially causing diarrhea and abdominal pain. Additional histologic features of Kaposi sarcoma include slit-like vascular spaces and extravasated erythrocytes.

Kaposi sarcoma of the skin appears similar to bacillary angiomatosis, which can also occur in HIV patients. However, bacillary angiomatosis is caused by Bartonella species, not HHV-8, and a skin biopsy of bacillary angiomatosis shows a neutrophilic rather than a lymphocytic infiltrate.

F) INCORRECT:

Cells with large mucin-filled vacuoles that displace the nucleus to the periphery are called Signet ring cells. Signet ring cell carcinoma is a type of adenocarcinoma and usually arises from the stomach. While this form of cancer can cause gastrointestinal upset such as diarrhea and abdominal pain, these lesions are not associated with HHV-8 infection.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of gastric tissue biopsy specimen (H&E stain)

Multiple signet-ring cells (round cells filled with mucin with a flat nucleus in the cell periphery; examples indicated by green overlay) can be seen.

This finding is diagnostic of signet-ring-cell carcinoma of the stomach.
questions.hint: This HIV-positive patient with a very low CD4+ T-lymphocyte count (< 200/mm3) presents with HHV-8-positive lesions, making Kaposi sarcoma the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician because of a skin lesion on his nose and in his mouth. The lesions have been gradually increasing in size and are not painful or pruritic. Two months ago, he was treated for esophageal candidiasis. Physical examination shows one pinkish-brown papule on the right wing of the nose and two similar nodular lesions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. A biopsy of one of the lesions shows spindle-shaped endothelial cells and infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Polyomavirus infection has been associated with Merkel cell carcinoma, an aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin that is much more frequent in HIV-infected individuals. However, unlike this patient's pinkish-brown papules, Merkel cell carcinoma appears as flesh-colored or bluish-red nodules. Skin biopsy is diagnostic and typically reveals dermal proliferation of small, blue cells containing large nuclei with finely granular chromatin and inconspicuous nucleoli, and minimal cytoplasm.

B) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection that primarily presents with acute pneumonia but may disseminate and cause skin lesions, such as erythema nodosum. While erythema nodosum presents with subcutaneous nodules that are red to blue in color, as seen in this patient, they are typically painful and located on the pretibial surfaces. Biopsy shows a dimorphic fungus and spherules filled with endospores.
Image Description:

Poorly demarcated red nodules are seen on the extensor sides of both lower legs with peripheral edema of the lower left leg and foot.

These findings are characteristic of erythema nodosum.

C) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum is caused by infection with poxvirus and characterized by nontender, skin-colored, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication mainly occurring on the trunk, face, and genitalia. It is rarely seen in immunocompetent adults; but in immunosuppressed individuals like this patient, lesions can be large, widespread, and persistent. However, this patient's pinkish-brown papules are inconsistent with molluscum contagiosum. A skin biopsy will be characteristic of hypergranulosis and molluscum bodies, which are hallmarks of the disease.
Image Description:

Several singular and partially confluent papules with central umbilication are visible at the lateral orbital rim.

These features are characteristic of molluscum contagiosum due to infection with molluscum contagiosum virus (poxvirus).

D) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infections can cause bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients. Infection causes vascular proliferation, which leads to development of multiple red or flesh-colored papules that bleed easily. While the papules can appear very similar to the lesions seen in this patient, biopsy findings typically show clusters of bacilli and neutrophilic infiltration, as opposed to the spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltration found in his biopsy.
Image Description:

Two angioma-like lesions with a surrounding erythematous halo are visible.

This immunocompromised patient was diagnosed with bacillary angiomatosis due to Bartonella quintana.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with HIV, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection can cause oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL). However, OHL only affects the oral mucosa, and the lesions are typically painless, nonscrapable white plaques with a feathery or hairy appearance, unlike this patient's pinkish-brown lesions. While chronic persistence of EBV is also associated with several tumor entities (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma, endemic Burkitt lymphoma), cutaneous lesions would not be the initial manifestation of these diseases.
Image Description:

A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

F) CORRECT:

This patient's skin lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma, the most common HIV-associated malignant tumor disease. The condition is caused by HHV 8 and manifests with multiple rapidly growing, painless cutaneous tumors that typically affect the face, chest, heels, and oral cavity. Skin biopsy is key to distinguishing this condition from bacillary angiomatosis, which is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration and inflammation.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

G) INCORRECT:

Human T-cell leukemia virus (HTLV) type 1 is an RNA virus involved in the pathogenesis of adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma (ATL) and HTLV-associated myelopathy. Acute ATL can present with skin lesions such as nodules, ulcers, and generalized papular rash. However, biopsy characteristically shows medium-sized lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and bizarre hypersegmented nuclei, as opposed to the spindle-shaped cells seen in this patient's biopsy. Moreover, further symptoms such as lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and pulmonary infiltrates would be expected.

H) INCORRECT:

Human papilloma virus 16 (HPV-16) is a high-risk HPV type associated with numerous medical conditions, including Bowen's disease, a squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin. Unlike this patient's pinkish-brown lesions, Bowen's disease manifests with erythematous and scaly plaques with irregularly shaped and sharply defined borders. HIV infection is, in fact, associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but biopsy of bowenoid lesions would show mild dysplastic features with an acanthotic epidermis.
Image Description:

Photograph of an area of skin on a patient's trunk

A well-defined erythematous plaque with scaling is visible.

This is the typical appearance of Bowen disease, i.e., squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin

I) INCORRECT:

Human papilloma virus 6 (HPV-6) is a low-risk HPV type that causes exophytic cauliflower-like lesions appearing as anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata) or laryngeal papillomatosis. HIV infection is in fact associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but biopsy of HPV-associated lesions characteristically shows hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, parakeratosis, and koilocytes. Moreover, oral lesions are primarily caused by HPV-16 and are usually malignant.

J) INCORRECT:

Infection with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is a common AIDS-defining condition. However, MAC infection causes fever, weight loss, lymphadenopathy, anemia, and abdominal pain; it does not present with skin lesions. Diagnosis is confirmed by isolation of MAC from blood or lymph nodes.
questions.hint: This patient's history of esophageal candidiasis is indicative of severe immunodeficiency. Spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltration seen on biopsy are pathognomonic for a particular AIDS-defining condition that may be mistaken for bacillary angiomatosis.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman with HIV presents with a chief complaint of intermittent wheezing and rare hemoptysis. She has also noticed a violaceous, nodular rash spreading across her trunk and lower extremities. She discontinued antiretroviral therapy more than one year ago, and her current CD4 count is 159 cells/mm3 (reference range, 400–1600).
Spirometry testing documents an FEV1 /FVC ratio of 63%. A chest radiograph reveals no parenchymal abnormalities. Bronchoscopy shows endobronchial violaceous macules in the lower airways.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Pneumocystis jirovecii rarely cause endobronchial lesions.

B) INCORRECT:

Mycobacterium tuberculosis and Pneumocystis jirovecii rarely cause endobronchial lesions.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with HIV are at increased risk for non-Hodgkin lymphoma when they have a CD4 count <100 cells/mm3, and endobronchial involvement is very rare.

D) INCORRECT:

Lesions associated with invasive Aspergillus infection tend to be ulcerated and necrotic in appearance.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s presentation is most consistent with Kaposi sarcoma (KS) of both the skin (explaining the rash) and the lungs (explaining the wheezing, hemoptysis, and obstructive findings on pulmonary function testing). KS occurs frequently in people with HIV, and its presence establishes the diagnosis of AIDS. Thoracic KS — which can involve the lung parenchyma, airways, and pleura — tends to occur in conjunction with extrapulmonary disease (e.g., of the skin and gastrointestinal tract).

Endobronchial KS can have normal imaging, as seen in this case, but can be diagnosed on bronchoscopy even without a biopsy, using the characteristic appearance of the lesions alone. The lesions, which are almost always erythematous, tend to be found as discrete macules or papules in the proximal airways but as confluent, hyperemic patches in the distal airways.

Key learning point: The diagnosis that should be considered in a patient with HIV infection who presents with wheezing, endobronchial lesions, and a violaceous rash is Kaposi sarcoma.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old man presents with skin lesions on both lower extremities that appeared about 6 months ago and have been growing in size. His history is significant for human herpesvirus 8 seropositivity and two kidney allografts. The first allograft was rejected; the second was done 2 years ago. The patient reports that he had similar lesions about 4 years ago, but they healed after he stopped immunosuppressive therapy following the allograft rejection.
Physical examination reveals symmetric, bilateral, purplish-blue plaques and nodules on the lower extremities that feel spongy upon palpation. The patient denies any pain or itching.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell and basal-cell carcinomas account for more than 90% of all skin cancers in transplant recipients but are typically located on the hands, forearms, or upper trunk in younger patients and on the head in older patients. Basal-cell carcinoma typically appears as a pearly white, dome-shaped papule with prominent telangiectatic surface vessels.

B) CORRECT:

Patients who receive immunosuppression following organ transplantation are at risk for several skin manifestations. Kaposi sarcoma is the most common among patients who are seropositive for human herpesvirus 8 before transplantation. In post-transplant patients, the classic purplish-blue lesions of Kaposi sarcoma typically appear on the lower extremities.

Key learning point: Patients with human herpesvirus 8 seropositivity who undergo transplantation and immunosuppression have a high risk for developing Kaposi sarcoma.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

C) INCORRECT:

Squamous-cell and basal-cell carcinomas account for more than 90% of all skin cancers in transplant recipients but are typically located on the hands, forearms, or upper trunk in younger patients and on the head in older patients. Squamous-cell carcinoma most commonly appears as a firm, smooth, or hyperkeratotic papule or plaque, often with central ulceration.

D) INCORRECT:

Malignant fibrous histiocytomas of the skin are rare and may mimic the appearance of basal- or squamous-cell carcinomas. They can occur after transplantation but are typically described as erythematous, beefy, sessile solitary nodules.

E) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster is a common viral skin infection that occurs in immunosuppressed individuals. The lesions are usually vesicular, painful, and present in distinct dermatomes.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man presents with a painless rash that first appeared on his right foot 8 months ago and has progressively moved up his leg. He was diagnosed with HIV infection more than one year ago, when he was admitted to the hospital for pneumocystis pneumonia, but he did not follow up after being discharged from the hospital.
On physical examination, his right leg has multiple purplish-blue nodules and plaques of varying sizes associated with 1+ pitting edema. His CD4 count is 34 cells per mm3 (reference range, 400–1600).
In addition to antiretroviral therapy, what is the best initial management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The presence of multiple purplish-blue skin nodules in a person with HIV is indicative of Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining malignancy. Chemotherapies, such as pegylated anthracyclines, are often used to treat more advanced or visceral Kaposi sarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

The presence of multiple purplish-blue skin nodules in a person with HIV is indicative of Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining malignancy. Plasma exchange is used to treat disorders such as thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura but not Kaposi sarcoma.

C) CORRECT:

The presence of multiple purplish-blue skin nodules in a person with HIV is indicative of Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining malignancy. All people with HIV should be treated with antiretroviral therapy. If they have asymptomatic, localized Kaposi sarcoma, then initiation of therapy would be expected to cause the rash to recede as CD4-cell counts improve and HIV viral load declines. On occasion, there is transient worsening because of the enhanced inflammatory response associated with immune reconstitution. This process, termed the immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome, is most commonly seen in patients, such as this one, who have advanced HIV-related immunosuppression. Severe cases may require systemic chemotherapy, systemic glucocorticoids, or both.

Despite the risk of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome, combination antiretroviral treatment is clearly the first priority in this patient, both to control the Kaposi sarcoma and to prevent other HIV-related complications.

Key learning point: Asymptomatic, localized Kaposi sarcoma is managed by close observation after initiation of antiretroviral therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

The presence of multiple purplish-blue skin nodules in a person with HIV is indicative of Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining malignancy. Intramuscular penicillin is a treatment for primary and secondary syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Systemic glucocorticoids may have a role in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma complicated by the immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome, but topical glucocorticoids are not used.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man presents with new but persistent plaques on his extremities (figure) and on his hard palate. He was diagnosed with HIV infection 10 years ago and has been taking tenofovir, emtricitabine, and efavirenz for the past 5 years. Six months ago, his CD4 count was 360 cells/mm3 (reference range, 400–1600), and his viral load was undetectable.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyogenic granulomas are discrete vascular tumors that commonly appear as papules or papulonodules. They can be seen in people with HIV, especially those taking protease inhibitors, but multiple plaques would be an uncommon presentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Lichen planus manifests with pruritic, violaceous, flat-topped papules; oral lichen planus more commonly manifests with reticulated white patches on the buccal mucosa. Lichen planus may be associated with hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection; it would be a consideration in a patient with HIV/HCV coinfection.

C) INCORRECT:

Bacillary angiomatosis in people with HIV occurs most often with CD4 counts that are <100 cells/mm3 and can manifest similarly to kaposi sarcoma, but it would be unusual with a CD4 count of 360 cells/mm3 .

D) CORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) associated with HIV infection typically occurs in patients with a low CD4 count (<150 cells/mm3 ; reference range, 400–1600) and a high viral load (>10,000 copies/mL). However, HIV-associated KS has also occasionally been reported in patients with a high CD4-cell count and low viral load who have been on long-term antiretroviral therapy. These patients appear to have an indolent course of KS with no eruptive lesions or visceral involvement.

Key learning point: Kaposi sarcoma should be considered the most likely cause of violaceous plaques on the skin in people with HIV, even when the HIV is well controlled.

E) INCORRECT:

Leukemia cutis can manifest as violaceous papules and plaques, but this would not be the most common presentation in the setting of HIV infection.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to the office because of a skin lesion on his nose and in his mouth. The lesions have been gradually increasing in size and are not painful or pruritic. Two months ago, he was treated for esophageal candidiasis. Physical examination shows two pinkish-brown papules on the nose and two similar nodular lesions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. A biopsy of one of the lesions shows spindle-shaped endothelial cells and infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with HIV, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection can cause oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL). However, OHL only affects the oral mucosa, and the lesions are typically painless, nonscrapable white plaques with a feathery or hairy appearance, unlike this patient's pinkish-brown lesions. While chronic persistence of EBV is also associated with several tumor entities (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma, endemic Burkitt lymphoma), cutaneous lesions would not be the initial manifestation of these diseases.
Image Description:

A 3–5 cm confluent, white plaque with a hairy appearance is seen across the left lateral side of the tongue that, in this case, could not be scraped off using a spatula.

This clinical finding is characteristic of oral hairy leukoplakia.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's skin lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma, the most common HIV-associated malignant tumor disease. The condition is caused by HHV 8 and manifests with multiple rapidly growing, painless cutaneous tumors that typically affect the face, chest, heels, and oral cavity. Skin biopsy is key to distinguishing this condition from bacillary angiomatosis, which is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration and inflammation.
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

C) INCORRECT:

Human T-cell leukemia virus (HTLV) type 1 is an RNA virus involved in the pathogenesis of adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma (ATL) and HTLV-associated myelopathy. Acute ATL can present with skin lesions such as nodules, ulcers, and generalized papular rash. However, biopsy characteristically shows medium-sized lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and bizarre hypersegmented nuclei, as opposed to the spindle-shaped cells seen in this patient's biopsy. Moreover, further symptoms such as lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and pulmonary infiltrates would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

Human papilloma virus 16 (HPV-16) is a high-risk HPV type associated with numerous medical conditions, including Bowen's disease, a squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin. Unlike this patient's pinkish-brown lesions, Bowen's disease manifests with erythematous and scaly plaques with irregularly shaped and sharply defined borders. HIV infection is, in fact, associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but biopsy of bowenoid lesions would show mild dysplastic features with an acanthotic epidermis.
Image Description:

Photograph of an area of skin on a patient's trunk

A well-defined erythematous plaque with scaling is visible.

This is the typical appearance of Bowen disease, i.e., squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin

E) INCORRECT:

Human papilloma virus 6 (HPV-6) is a low-risk HPV type that causes exophytic cauliflower-like lesions appearing as anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata) or laryngeal papillomatosis. HIV infection is in fact associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but biopsy of HPV-associated lesions characteristically shows hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, parakeratosis, and koilocytes. Moreover, oral lesions are primarily caused by HPV-16 and are usually malignant.
questions.hint: This patient's history of esophageal candidiasis is indicative of severe immunodeficiency. Spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltration seen on biopsy are pathognomonic for a particular AIDS-defining condition that may be mistaken for bacillary angiomatosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV comes to your clinic because of multiple lesions on his lower extremities. The lesions have been increasing in size and are neither painful nor pruritic. He does not have lymphadenopathy. He works at a garden center and lives in Ontario. His medications include abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine. His temperature is 37.7°C, pulse is 75/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. On examination, there are multiple lesions on both heels, some of which are elevated, and two similar lesions on the chest. An image of his right heel is provided. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450 cells/μL (500–2000). A skin biopsy reveals multiple spindle-shaped cells and leukocyte infiltration. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a malignant, highly vascularized tumor that most commonly affects the skin and is caused by human herpesvirus 8. It is the most common HIV-associated tumor and can occur at any CD4 count. This tumor initially manifests with multiple rapidly growing, painless cutaneous tumors that typically affect the face, chest, heels, and oral cavity. If left untreated, the tumor may disseminate to the organs (e.g., gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract). KS skin lesions resemble those of bacillary angiomatosis; histology is required to differentiate between the conditions. The diagnosis is confirmed with skin biopsy findings of spindle-shaped cells, leukocyte infiltration, and signs of angiogenesis.

Key learning point: Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular tumor most commonly seen in HIV patients and is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).

B) INCORRECT:

Trichophyton rubrum is a fungus that causes tinea, but it is not associated with Kaposi sarcoma. While the condition can affect any body part and could occur on the heels and chest simultaneously, the lesions manifest as pruritic, erythematous plaques with scaling, raised borders. A KOH stain of a skin sample would show a fungus with segmented hyphae.

C) INCORRECT:

Coccidioides immitis causes coccidioidomycosis, a fungal infection that primarily manifests with acute pneumonia but that can disseminate and cause erythema nodosum. While erythema nodosum also presents with subcutaneous nodules that are red to blue in color, they are painful and typically located on the pretibial surfaces. Biopsy findings show a dimorphic fungus and spherules filled with endospores. Additionally, coccidioidomycosis is not endemic to Canada and is unlikely in a patient with no history of travel to an endemic region (e.g., southwestern United States, Central America).

D) INCORRECT:

Bartonella henselae infections can cause bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients. The infection leads to vascular proliferation, which can manifest as multiple red papules that bleed easily. Biopsy findings of the lesion may also show an inflammatory infiltrate, but spindle-shaped cells are not characteristic of bacillary angiomatosis. Moreover, bacillary angiomatosis is most common in patients with a CD4 count < 100 cells/μL.

E) INCORRECT:

Sporothrix schenckii is a fungus that causes sporotrichosis, a disease that is mainly transmitted through contact with contaminated soil or plants, e.g., while gardening. Several red to purple nodules may develop around the initial lesion, which forms at the inoculation site (typically the hands or arms). While this patient's risk of contracting sporotrichosis is increased because of his profession, biopsy findings are consistent with Kaposi sarcoma, which is not associated with S. schenckii infection.
questions.hint: The purple-bluish lesions seen in this patient with HIV are consistent with Kaposi sarcomas.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to your clinic with multiple lesions on his chest and lower extremities. The lesions have gradually increased in size and are neither painful nor pruritic. He was diagnosed with HIV infection seven years ago. His current medications are abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine. A photograph of the lesions is provided. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 450 cells/μL (500–2000). Skin biopsy reveals multiple spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltrate. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline is used for the treatment of infectious diseases such as Bacillary angiomatosis, a condition caused by the bacterium Bartonella henselae. Bacillary angiomatosis is often seen in patients with AIDS. It can also manifest with multiple painless violaceous nodules on the skin and is, therefore, an important differential diagnosis for Kaposi sarcoma. However, a biopsy of these lesions is likely to show neutrophilic infiltration rather than the lymphocytic infiltration seen in this patient. Doxycycline would not be effective in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Nitazoxanide is an antiparasitic agent used in the treatment of Cryptosporidium parvum and Giardia lamblia infection. This patient with HIV is at increased risk of protozoa infection. However, these parasites cause chronic nonbloody diarrhea without any cutaneous manifestations. Nitazoxanide would not be effective in the treatment of KS.

C) INCORRECT:

Amphotericin B is an antifungal agent used in the treatment of severe fungal infections such as histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, and cryptococcosis, which can occasionally present with cutaneous manifestations. However, these conditions are typically associated with a lower CD4+ count (< 250//μL in coccidiomycosis, < 150/μL in histoplasmosis and cryptococcosis) and other features of these fungal infections (e.g., pneumonia-like illness in coccidiomycosis and histoplasmosis, meningitis in cryptococcosis) are not present. Amphotericin B would not be effective in the treatment of Kaposi sarcoma.

D) CORRECT:

Alpha-interferon (IFN-α) is a biologic modifier that can be used in the treatment of KS. This type of sarcoma can be caused by HHV-8 infection and is an AIDS-defining illness. KS can occur at any CD4+ count but is more likely to develop if CD4+ count is < 500 cells/μL. How IFN-α fights cancer cells is not fully understood; upregulation of the immune response is thought to play a role. IFN-α is also used in the treatment of hepatitis B and C infections.

Key learning point: Alpha-interferon is an effective immunomodulatory therapy for Kaposi sarcoma, an AIDS-defining illness caused by HHV-8, especially in HIV-infected patients with cutaneous lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Ganciclovir is an antiviral agent used in the treatment of several viral infections, especially cytomegalovirus (CMV). Infection with CMV is common in immunocompromised patients, including patients with HIV. However, the most common sequelae include CMV retinitis, esophagitis, pneumonitis, and encephalitis – not skin lesions. Ganciclovir would not be effective in the treatment of KS.
questions.hint: In a patient with HIV, multiple painless violaceous skin lesions that progress in size point toward Kaposi sarcoma (KS). Spindle cells and lymphocytic infiltrate on skin biopsy confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man comes to your clinic because of a skin lesion on his nose and a lesion in his mouth. The lesions have been gradually increasing in size and are not painful or pruritic. Two months ago, he was treated for esophageal candidiasis. On examination, there are two pinkish-brown papules on the nose and two similar nodular lesions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. Biopsy of one lesion shows spindle-shaped endothelial cells with infiltration of lymphocytes, plasma cells, and macrophages. Which one of the following is the most likely causal organism of his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Human papilloma virus 6 (HPV-6) is a low-risk HPV type that causes exophytic cauliflower-like lesions appearing as anogenital warts (condylomata acuminata) or laryngeal papillomatosis. HIV infection is in fact associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but biopsy of HPV-associated lesions characteristically shows hyperkeratosis, papillomatosis, parakeratosis, and koilocytes. Moreover, oral lesions are primarily caused by HPV-16 and are usually malignant.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's skin lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma, the most common HIV-associated malignant tumor disease. The condition is caused by HHV 8 and manifests with multiple rapidly growing, painless cutaneous tumors that typically affect the face, chest, heels, and oral cavity. Skin biopsy is key to distinguishing this condition from bacillary angiomatosis, which is characterized by neutrophilic infiltration and inflammation.

Key learning point: Kaposi sarcoma, a common HIV-associated malignancy with painless cutaneous and oral lesions, is caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).
Image Description:

A mixture of dark red macules, papules, and plaques are distributed asymmetrically on the skin.

These lesions are characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma (caused by human herpesvirus 8).

C) INCORRECT:

Human papilloma virus 16 (HPV-16) is a high-risk HPV type associated with numerous medical conditions, including Bowen's disease, a squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin. Unlike this patient's pinkish-brown lesions, Bowen's disease manifests with erythematous and scaly plaques with irregularly shaped and sharply defined borders. HIV infection is, in fact, associated with an increased prevalence of HPV infection, but biopsy of bowenoid lesions would show mild dysplastic features with an acanthotic epidermis.

D) INCORRECT:

Human T-cell leukemia virus (HTLV) type 1 is an RNA virus involved in the pathogenesis of adult T cell leukemia-lymphoma (ATL) and HTLV-associated myelopathy. Acute ATL can present with skin lesions such as nodules, ulcers, and generalized papular rash. However, biopsy characteristically shows medium-sized lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and bizarre hypersegmented nuclei, as opposed to the spindle-shaped cells seen in this patient's biopsy. Moreover, further symptoms such as lytic bone lesions, hypercalcemia, and pulmonary infiltrates would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with HIV, Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection can cause oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL). However, OHL only affects the oral mucosa, and the lesions are typically painless, nonscrapable white plaques with a feathery or hairy appearance, unlike this patient's pinkish-brown lesions. While chronic persistence of EBV is also associated with several tumor entities (e.g., Hodgkin lymphoma, endemic Burkitt lymphoma), cutaneous lesions would not be the initial manifestation of these diseases.
questions.hint: This patient's history of esophageal candidiasis is indicative of severe immunodeficiency. Spindle-shaped cells and lymphocytic infiltration seen on biopsy are pathognomonic for a particular AIDS-defining condition that may be mistaken for bacillary angiomatosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with several painless, dark purple on his nose (see photo) that have appeared over the past month. He reports no systemic symptoms. The lesions are non-tender, non-friable, and do not blanch with pressure. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Prescribe topical corticosteroids and schedule dermatology follow-up
Treat empirically for bacillary angiomatosis with doxycycline therapy
Start empirical antibiotics for suspected cellulitis
Obtain urgent dermatology consultation for suspected malignant melanoma

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Topical corticosteroids would not be appropriate for these nodules as they are not inflammatory and would not respond to steroid treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

While bacillary angiomatosis is a reasonable differential diagnosis for this condition, another condition is more likely, and treatment of bacillary angiomatosis is also usually initiated after biopsy confirmation.

C) INCORRECT:

The violaceous, non-tender nodules described are not consistent with bacterial cellulitis, which typically presents with erythema, warmth, tenderness, and potential systemic symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the dark pigmentation might raise concern for melanoma, the violaceous color and nodular appearance are more of an alternate diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – The clinical presentation of multiple painless, violaceous skin nodules is highly suspicious for Kaposi sarcoma. HIV screening is essential as Kaposi sarcoma is the most common HIV-associated tumor.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of HIV, non-adherent to antiretroviral therapy, presents for evaluation of new skin lesions on his lower extremities and hard palate. His most recent CD4 count was 150 cells/mm3. A photograph of the lesions is shown. A biopsy is performed for definitive diagnosis. This patient's condition is most strongly associated with which of the following pathogens?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Kaposi sarcoma is a vascular malignancy caused by infection with human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8). This pathogen infects endothelial cells and induces their proliferation and transformation through viral oncogenes, leading to the formation of these characteristic vascular lesions. While lesions can appear anywhere, common locations include the lower extremities, face, and oral cavity, particularly the hard palate. Management primarily involves initiating or optimizing antiretroviral therapy to restore immune function.

B) INCORRECT:

Infection with Bartonella species can cause bacillary angiomatosis in immunocompromised patients, presenting as reddish-purple vascular papules and nodules that can be clinically indistinguishable from this patient's lesions. However, this condition is less common than Kaposi sarcoma in patients with AIDS.

C) INCORRECT:

Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), or HHV-4, is associated with several malignancies in patients with HIV, including primary CNS lymphoma and oral hairy leukoplakia. However, this patient's lesions are not characteristic of an EBV-related condition. Oral hairy leukoplakia presents as white, non-scrapable plaques on the lateral tongue, which this patient does not have.

D) INCORRECT:

Cytomegalovirus (CMV), or HHV-5, is a common opportunistic infection in patients with advanced AIDS, typically with a CD4 count below 50 cells/mm3. It most commonly causes retinitis, colitis, or esophagitis. While CMV can cause cutaneous manifestations such as ulcers, they do not have the violaceous, maculopapular appearance seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Human papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with an increased risk of squamous cell carcinomas, particularly anogenital and oropharyngeal cancers, in individuals with HIV. However, HPV-related lesions typically appear as verrucous warts (condylomata) or ulcerative carcinomas, not the violaceous lesions seen in this patient.
questions.hint: Violaceous macules, papules, and plaques distributed asymmetrically on the skin in a patient with HIV infection and a CD4 count below 200 cells/mm3 are highly characteristic of Kaposi sarcoma.
